$description: Core breakpoint and content width primitives for responsive design. Breakpoints use em units for accessibility (respect user font size preferences). Based on common device categories but designed for content-first responsive design, not device-specific layouts.

breakpoints.$description: Viewport width breakpoints for media queries. Use mobile-first approach: base styles for mobile, then layer on complexity at larger breakpoints. Values in em units = px/16. USAGE: @media (min-width: TOKEN_VALUE) for progressive enhancement.

xs.$description: Extra small breakpoint (576px). Use for: large phones in landscape, small tablets. Content starts having room to breathe. Typical changes: side-by-side layouts begin, hiding mobile-only elements. Above this: no longer 'mobile-only' context.

sm.$description: Small breakpoint (768px). Use for: tablets in portrait, small laptops. Two-column layouts become comfortable. Typical changes: sidebars can appear, cards go 2-up, navigation expands. Common tablet breakpoint. Desktop-like experiences begin here.

md.$description: Medium breakpoint (992px). Use for: tablets in landscape, standard laptops, small desktops. Full desktop layouts are comfortable. Typical changes: three-column layouts, full navigation, expanded sidebars. Most 'desktop' designs target this minimum.

lg.$description: Large breakpoint (1200px). Use for: large laptops, standard desktop monitors. Generous space available. Typical changes: four-column grids, expanded dashboards, side panels. Content max-widths often kick in here to prevent over-stretching.

xl.$description: Extra large breakpoint (1408px). Use for: large desktop monitors, high-resolution displays. Maximum layouts. Typical changes: ultra-wide layouts, multi-panel views, data-dense dashboards. Consider max-width constraints - too wide hurts readability.

contentWidth.$description: Maximum content width constraints for readability and layout control. Apply as max-width on content containers. Prevents content from stretching uncomfortably wide on large screens.

sm.$description: Small content width (600px). Use for: prose content, documentation, blog posts, reading-focused layouts. Optimal line length for readability (~65-75 characters). Common in: article bodies, help documentation, settings panels, narrow modals.

lg.$description: Large content width (1280px). Use for: full application layouts, dashboards, data-heavy interfaces. Maximum comfortable width for most content. Common in: main app container, dashboard layouts, admin interfaces. Beyond this, consider multi-column or sidebar layouts.
